''The mere use of one's eyes in Venice is happiness enough.''

VENICE is a city virtually upholstered with masterpieces, and during the 52nd Biennale, which began June 10 and includes 76 countries, hundreds of artists and too many satellite events to count or see, official-art-world fatigue could set in quickly.

One way to alleviate it is to follow the advice of honorary Venetians like James, who counseled simply looking at the city itself, that ''vast museum where the little wicket that admits you is perpetually turning and creaking.''

Around the corner of almost every campo and palazzo are works of art, readymades created by time and chance, burnished by decay. With so much contemporary art on view, a city of the Byzantine, the Baroque and the Gothic can even give itself over to a more modern view.

A tablecloth flapping from a clothesline can stand in for a Jasper Johns target. A tacked-up sign at a cemetery counseling female mourners to dress demurely can conjure Rauschenberg. An ancient fountain and coiled water hose near St. Mark's square can be a Joseph Beuys or a companion piece to a brand-new work on view at the Biennale by Bruce Nauman, in which reversed molds of human heads spout water into utility sinks below.

It's a great game to play in a city that has rewarded close attention for centuries. ''She has a thousand occasional graces and is always liable to happy accidents,'' James wrote. ''You become extraordinarily fond of these things; you count upon them; they make part of your life.''
